header.title: PAPYRI GRAECAE MAGICAE. DIE GRIECHISCHEN ZAUBERPAPYRI

central_thesis: Preisendanz's PGM serves as the definitive scholarly collection, critical edition, and German translation of the primary source texts of Greco-Egyptian magic. Its central thesis is to systematically present these ancient papyri, offering unparalleled insight into the practical magical, religious, and philosophical landscape of late antiquity. It reveals a highly syncretic magical tradition that blended Egyptian, Greek, Jewish, and early Christian/Gnostic elements, providing rituals for virtually every human desire and fear, from love and wealth to protection and revenge, thus making these foundational texts accessible for academic study and practical exploration (published 1928).

structure_content.summary: This section provides extensive historical context for the discovery and scholarly study of the Greek Magical Papyri. It outlines the academic challenges in compiling and translating these fragmented texts, acknowledges foundational contributions by scholars like Albrecht Dieterich and Richard Wünsch, and details the collaborative academic endeavor undertaken for this edition. It highlights the interdisciplinary nature of the research, involving papyrology, philology, and religious history, and discusses the editorial plan and the significance of key papyri like Papyrus Mimaut and Papyrus British Museum XLVI.

This forms the core of the work, presenting a meticulous critical edition of transcribed Greek texts from various papyri alongside their German translations. Each major papyrus (e.g., Pap. Berlin 5025, Pap. Louvre 2391, Pap. Bibl. Nat. suppl. gr. 574, Pap. Brit. Mus. XLVI, Pap. Holm. Blat. o. S., Pap. Brit. Mus. XLVII) is treated distinctly, with its content, linguistic nuances, and ritualistic instructions analyzed. This section provides direct access to the ancient magical formulae, prayers, and operational instructions.

This section includes photographic reproductions or detailed drawings of selected fragments of the papyri, magical amulets, and symbolic representations described within the texts. Examples include 'P II 152-161 mit Skarabäeus' (with scarab), 'P II 166 mit kopflosem Dämon' (headless demon), 'P III 70 mit Seth', 'P III 196-97: Schlange um Dreifuß' (snake around tripod), 'P V 83: Ulat mit Vokalen' (Ulat with vowels), and 'P V 357: magischer Ring mit Zauberworten' (magical ring with words of power). These visual aids are crucial for understanding the material culture and symbolic imagery integral to the magical practices.

key_concepts.definition: The collection of ancient Greek magical papyri, predominantly from Greco-Roman Egypt, which serves as the foundational text for this academic and practical study. These texts do not represent a single coherent system but rather a diverse compilation of various magical traditions.

The most defining characteristic of PGM magic, involving the amalgamation of religious and magical elements from Greek, Egyptian, Jewish, Babylonian, and Gnostic traditions. This is evident in the invocation of deities under multiple names (e.g., Helios-Apollo-Mithras-Osiris) and the integration of diverse cultural symbols and practices.

Untranslatable, often seemingly nonsensical strings of vowels or consonants (e.g., 'Ablanathanalba,' 'Abrasax,' 'Iaō,' 'Iaō-Sabaoath'), believed to possess inherent magical power. These words are a core and often essential component of almost every ritual within the PGM.

Intricate, often abstract drawings and symbols inscribed on amulets, papyri, or other ritual objects. These are understood not as mere decorations but as potent representations of divine powers, spirits, or cosmic forces, acting as visual keys to activate and direct magical operations.

The PGM contains practices that fluidly transition between what later traditions would categorize as theurgy (invoking or compelling divine beings for beneficial purposes such as divination or healing) and goetia (binding, cursing, or compelling individuals for personal gain, love, or revenge, often involving lower-ranking spirits or the deceased). The distinction is often blurred, with both types of operations frequently employing similar techniques.

The explicit and precise invocation of a multitude of divine and demonic names, often in lengthy sequences. Knowledge and correct pronunciation of these names were believed to grant the practitioner authority and influence over the invoked entities, as understanding a being's 'true' name was a source of power.

practical_system.description: The PGM presents a highly diverse range of magical practices, unified by a syncretic worldview that blends elements from Greek, Egyptian, Jewish, and Gnostic traditions. The operations typically involve complex invocations, spells, and the creation of magical objects for various purposes, including love, wealth, protection, healing, divination, and revenge. The efficacy of these rituals is believed to stem from the precise use of divine names (Nomina Sacra), magical words (Voces Magicae), symbolic characters (Charakteres), and often specific ritual ingredients and strict adherence to astrological or chronological timings (e.g., planetary hours, moon phases). The system posits a cosmos populated by a hierarchy of gods, daemons, and spirits of the dead, all of whom can be compelled or persuaded through proper ritual means and knowledge.
tools: Papyrus, Parchment, Lead Tablets: Primary materials used for writing spells, letters to gods, and curse tablets (defixiones).
Amulets/Talismans: Crafted from various materials such as metals (gold, silver, lead), gemstones, or papyrus, meticulously inscribed with Charakteres and Voces Magicae.
Lamps and Bowls: Essential for many divination rites (e.g., lychnomancy, lekanomancy), and frequently used for offerings, or as focal points to create a charged ritual atmosphere.
Writing Implements and Inks: Specific reeds, pens, and specially prepared inks (sometimes mixed with blood, urine, or rare herbal concoctions) are prescribed for inscribing magical texts.
Herbs, Oils, Incense: Utilized extensively in offerings, fumigations, anointing the body or tools, and as vital components in complex magical preparations and unguents.
Statues, Images, Figurines: Representations of deities or human figures, serving as foci for invocation, as ritual offerings, or as targets for binding spells and curses.

Animal Sacrifices/Parts: While less central than in some other ancient traditions, specific animal parts (e.g., a lion's tongue for certain oracular spells) are occasionally prescribed as potent ritual ingredients.
Ritual Garments/Crowns: Specific types of clothing, head coverings, or crowns are sometimes instructed for the practitioner to wear during elaborate ceremonies to enhance ritual purity or authority.

Blood, Bodily Fluids: Infrequently, but significantly, prescribed as powerful ritual ingredients, particularly for binding spells, love charms, or certain types of evocations due to their perceived life force.
rituals: Theurgic Invocations: Elaborate prayers and calls to powerful deities (e.g., Helios, Selene, Hermes, Hekate, Osiris, Anubis, Iaō) to gain knowledge, power, or direct divine assistance. These often involve lengthy strings of divine names and epithets, aimed at compelling the deity to manifest or grant boons.

Binding Spells (Defixiones): Rituals designed to compel, constrain, or influence another person, commonly for love, sexual attraction, or to hinder rivals. These typically involve inscribing the spell on lead tablets or papyrus, sometimes with an image of the target, and then ritually disposing of them by burying or submerging.

Divination: Methods to predict the future or gain hidden information, including various forms of scrying such as lamp divination (lychnomancy), bowl divination (lekanomancy), dream oracles (oneiromancy), and direct communication with invoked spirits for prophecy.

Amulet Creation: Detailed instructions for inscribing magical words, symbols (Charakteres), and divine names on diverse materials (metals like gold or silver, stones, papyrus) to create protective charms, love charms, talismans for success, or general good fortune.

Healing and Protection: Spells and remedies intended to cure illnesses, ward off evil spirits, banish malevolent entities, or provide general protection for the practitioner, their household, or property.
Success and Prosperity Spells: Rituals aimed at securing favor, winning legal disputes or competitions, attracting customers for business, or ensuring financial gain and overall good fortune.

Nekyomancy: The evocation of the spirits of the dead for specific purposes, often to gain prophetic knowledge or to compel the deceased to act on behalf of the practitioner for coercive or revenge-oriented ends.

relevant_quotes.text: Nimm drei Blätter der Balsam-Pflanze und schreib auf sie mit Myrrhe-Tinte die Worte: ... Leg die Blätter unter die Zunge eines Löwen, und wenn er spricht, frage ihn alles, was du wissen willst, und er wird dir antworten.
Ich beschwöre dich, großer Gott, den Herrn des Himmels und der Erde, des Chaos und des Ethers, der sieben Planetensphären, der die Schlange im Abgrund hält, der du alle Dinge siehst und alles weißt.
So lege dich hin und sprich: 'Komm zu mir, [Name des Mannes/der Frau], und tue, was ich will.'

critical_analysis.relevance: Preisendanz's PGM is the seminal and indispensable scholarly compilation of the Greek Magical Papyri. It is the primary and authoritative source for understanding ancient Greco-Egyptian magic, providing direct access to the actual spells and rituals practiced in antiquity. Its meticulous editing, precise translation, and comprehensive indexing have established it as the foundational text for all subsequent academic studies in ancient magic, religion, and the history of esotericism. For practitioners, it offers a direct, unmediated connection to a rich, complex, and highly influential magical tradition, revealing the syncretic roots and operative techniques that informed many later Western magical currents, including Hermetic Qabalah and grimoire traditions.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience is academic scholars, including classicists, Egyptologists, historians of religion, philologists, and scholars of esotericism, who require access to foundational primary source material for their research. A significant secondary audience consists of practitioners of Western Esotericism—such as Ceremonial Magicians, Chaos Magicians, Hermeticists, and those working with grimoire magic—who seek to understand the historical precedents and operative techniques of ancient magic, or to adapt and apply these ancient methods within modern magical practice.
